posts.sub: Welcome to /his/ - History & Humanities
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14419642
North France - R1b-U152 and L21 - autosomally these samples are very northern, more than modern France, lots of Beaker ancestry.
South France - pretty similar to Iberians, much more southern. Similar haplogroups with some DF27.

Venetians - no samples. Closest thing are some Slovenian samples - R1b-U152 + J2b.

Illyrians - J2b with minor R1b-U152, G2a, I2. J2b was the dominant haplogroup since at least the bronze age Cetina culture. R1b probably came with Tumulus or Hallstatt and mixed with natives.
High EEF - 55-60% +.

Thracians - E-V13, probably also others (like R1b-Z2103 or even R1a-Z93 from Scythians). The samples are very Southern and Greek like - 60-70% EEF.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14422547
I've always read it as the Optimates being wildly out-of-touch with the "average" Roman citizen. The Optimates were afraid that Populares like Caesar would strip them of ancient rights and powers and so they used the "he's a tyrant!" excuse thinking the average Roman would never question such a serious claim. You have to remember that tyranny/monarchy was the worst crime to a classical Roman.

I think the Optimates underestimated both how popular Caesar was personally, and how little support they really had among the powerful elite. The Optimates assumed that all the old and powerful families would side with them, in the end, rather than rally behind a dead tyrant. But many of those families could see which way the wind was blowing and figured that controlling inevitable reform is better than getting crushed by it.

So really what it boils down to, is that the Optimates misread the situation and didn't understand just how badly their actions would be perceived, and how much the power of the Populares faction had grown among the wealthy and more elite families who realized after Sulla how powerful popular opinion could be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14422547
He had secured unprecedented personal power. His opponents hated him for personal/political reasons, but they wouldn't have risked killing him if they did not realize his ambitions posed an existential threat to the republic. The Roman people liked Caesar, simple as, and that excuse wasn't compelling enough. You can make a case for why Caesar's reforms etc. outweighed his other actions (both in terms of benefits to Rome and insofar as they factored into opposition to him), but at the end of the day he had secured an unprecedented lifetime dictatorship and was acting in a thoroughly unrepublican manner.

Once Caesar left to campaign against Parthia the Roman political class would have had essentially zero influence on him, and a victory would have meant Caesar returning at the head of an army with more than enough popularity to establish a new monarchy.

>>14422516
>How many Jews actually embraced Jesus as the Messiah in the first couple centuries after his death?
Difficult to say since we don't know exactly when Jesus lived, died, or if there was in fact even a historical Jesus.
Christianity seems to have been a survival of the popular proto-orthodox version of Judaism that was still at least partially polytheistic.
Just one of many popular sects of Judaism that were present in the region at the time that many people would have been familiar with.
So when the Bible depicts the crowd in Jerusalem as being aware of what is going on in a Christian context that may be accurate.

However, the population in the diaspora were better educated and were more likely to subscribe to the ethical monotheist version of the faith, which is why it among the various Jewish sects is the one that survived to the modern day.

>What were the reasons why some Jews didn't recognise him as Messiah?
If there was a historical Jesus, he didn't make much of a splash outside of his sect. His claim of being a secret survivor of the old royal family (or the offspring of Yahweh as the old kings had claimed) wasn't exactly unique. Nor did he do any of the things that the general population expected from the Messiah. Lots of guys calling themselves "Jesus" who tried to fight the Romans or made a nuisance of themselves more generally got crucified. He just didn't really stand out from the crowd.

Christianity may have survived simply because its message was a neutered "monotheist" faith, had those surviving polytheistic elements which made it more acceptable to a Roman audience (but not the Jewish diaspora), and had a central figure with messages like "Pay your Taxes to Rome". Something which was good enough for Rome to adopt it as the official state religion and make it a forced meme.

Simon Bar Kokhba came a lot closer to satisfying the role, and actually had some high level backing, but of course the Romans didn't take kindly to that.

Modern Christian doctrine is essentially set up so that any attempt at an answer to the mystery of the trinity is a heresy. Simply to weed out anyone who will question leadership. The ancient arguments over those are basically proxy wars fought for greater power within the organization by different factions.

Thanks to modern Archaeology and textual examination we actually have a possible answer to this that isn't just attempting to glean meaning from the surface reading of words heavily edited by people with axes to grind.
The Father, El was the old chief deity of the pantheon that was worshiped in the region prior to the monotheistic reformation.
The Son, Yahweh was the young virile war god who fought the chaos dragon leviathan to create the world, died, and resurrected to become the new king of the gods.
The 'holy spirit' may be a survival of Asherah the goddess consort of Yahweh who anointed him with oil to make him king of the gods / bring him back to life.
But may also simply be based on the 'Priestly' deity that was an even older more cosmic impersonal deity that was worshiped in the Temple as well (as a member of the older generation of gods, he was a serpent. Yes that one from Genesis. No not Satan that's a later addition to the pantheon).

Christianity was heavily influenced by surviving polytheistic strains within Judaism. Jesus may be interpreted as a new generation in this mythic cycle, or he may simply be meant to be an incarnation of Yahweh himself.
The confusion of El and Yahweh into a single deity may not really be that strange, the royal cult in most of these cultures saw the gods as a reflection of the King.
So the King when he's young and newly enthroned after being anointed with oil is like the resurrected Yahweh, reborn in to power and when he's old and wise he's like El Elyon who doled out the nations to his sons.

>>14420550
>How do the Orthodox cope with the fact that God clearly favors the Catholic Church, historically speaking?
It is difficult to draw a clear understanding of the purposes of Divine Providence from such historical events, e.g., inferring that God is punishing someone because something bad happened to that person.

Jesus expressly refutes such reasoning in John 9:2-3:
>2 and His disciples asked Him, “Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?”
>3 “Neither this man nor his parents sinned, but this happened so that the works of God might be displayed in him."

In the disciples' understanding, those who suffered must have "deserved it," or at least someone in their family did.

Jesus responds that personal suffering is not *necessarily* linked to one's own personal sin. In a broad sense, all suffering is a result of sin—aftershocks of the fall of man through Adam (Romans 5:12).

Everything from political unrest to poverty to hunger are grounded in humanity rejecting their created purpose. But, as this man's example shows, not all suffering is directly deserved, in and of itself. Hardship and suffering, including persecution, are not surefire signs of divine retribution.

With that said, I think the respective history of Orthodoxy and Catholicism is very incisively analyzed by Soloviev in his book The Russian Church and the Papacy, pic related.

Soloviev:
>The Eastern prays, the Western prays and labors. Which of the two is right?

>Jesus Christ founded His visible Church not merely to meditate on Heaven, but also to labor upon Earth and to withstand the gates of Hell. He did not send His apostles into the solitude of the desert, but into the world to conquer it and subject it to the Kingdom which is not of this world...

>We have in the East a Church at prayer, but where among us is the Church in action, asserting itself as a spiritual force absolutely independent of the powers of this world?

A gladiator (Latin: gladiator, "swordsman", from gladius, "sword") was an armed combatant who entertained audiences in the Roman Republic and Roman Empire in violent confrontations with other gladiators, wild animals, and condemned criminals. Some gladiators were volunteers who risked their lives and their legal and social standing by appearing in the arena. Most were despised as slaves, schooled under harsh conditions, socially marginalized, and segregated even in death.

this is for show, not a human offering

Modern customs and institutions offer few useful parallels to the legal and social context of the gladiatoria munera. In Roman law, anyone condemned to the arena or the gladiator schools (damnati ad ludum) was a servus poenae (slave of the penalty), and was considered to be under sentence of death unless manumitted. Only slaves found guilty of specific offences could be sentenced to the arena; however, citizens found guilty of particular offenses could be stripped of citizenship, formally enslaved, then sentenced; and slaves, once freed, could be legally reverted to slavery for certain offences. Arena punishment could be given for banditry, theft and arson, and for treasons such as rebellion, census evasion to avoid paying due taxes and refusal to swear lawful oaths

this is a capital punishment, not a human offering

>>14420432
There are a number of orthodox positions on hell, it's not absolutely settled even within strict dogmas like Catholicism or Greek Orthodoxy.

At any rate, the standard position is that anybody who CAN go to Heaven, WILL go to heaven, but they have to go through a sanitized easy-mode "hell" called purgatory. By all accounts this is a part of what is popularly considered Hell, but the stay is purely temporary, because the suffering in it purges all your sins and permits you to go on your merry way to heaven. Most people will go through this.
Some believe in annihilationism, that is that hell is simply nonexistence, and thus the only "eternal" element of the punishment is not existing, and since the people who are most likely to go to hell are the kind that are absorbed with the self, the self not existing is an apt punishment.

But the point is that God doesn't put you in hell, you choose to go there of your own free volition. Every path towards salvation is open to you at any time throughout your life (and possibly even your afterlife - some Christians are of the position that the inhabitants of Hell remain there because they refuse to ask for forgiveness from God, chief amongst them the Devil himself) and you have to actively choose not to take a step on that road.
You may think that deliberately choosing to go to hell may sound like an illogical premise, but the very notion of sin is ipso facto theological insanity - the active denial of the creator of all good things, including reason and intelligence itself.

This is Autonomous City of Buenos Aires (NOT all buenos aires, just this tiny part call CABA), the part in red is "La Boca", u can see the water going in the middle of the red part, that is the port and where there were many Conventillos.

Pure democracy is a terrible way to run a country but the thing is that the citizenry doesn't need to be 140 IQ people doing CIA detective work on politics, they're not the ones that are actually doing the governing and running the country. This is preferable to not even having the option to kick a shitty ruler out, except by civil war, which also makes the ruler less accountable in the end because people are going to be less willing to initiate a civil war compared to just voting out a poor leader.
I hear people use the "would you rather have a certified doctor or a random bunch of people perform surgery on you" analogy but really an accurate analogy would be "you are part of a group that will be operated on. >>14413994
The point of democracy is not that decisions taken by the uninformed majority are better than decisions taken by an informed expert, the point of democracy is separation of powers. It is the only system, in theory, in which the government is constantly scrutinised by legislators and judges, and the government is powerless to send people to jail or act as judge, jury and executioner. In other systems e.g. military dictatorships or absolute monarchies, all powers are concentrated in one person - of course this always depends on the specific case, for example dictator Mussolini was deposed by the legislative Council of Fascism, dictator Pinochet stepped down after losing a referendum, etc but that's the general idea. An absolute monarch is above the law; a feudal lord, a warlord, a sultan not only rules the land but acts as judge and legislator as well. This cannot happen in a democracy, by definition. Rule by majority is a secondary thing.

>>14413994
Look at the history. I don't think any side of the political spectrum likes this much, but the traditional inception of "democracy" was with Cleisthenes reforms in Athens. Cleisthenes was responding to the fallout of the overthrow of the Peisistratids. The Peisistratids were the family of the tyrant of Athens Pisistratis, who installed himself not long after Solon's reforms. "Tyranny" back then wasn't as loaded as it is now, to be a tyrant was merely to be a ruler outside the bounds of normal law or constitutional order. But tyrants weren't always perceived as de facto "bad". While they were understood to be ultimately illegitimate under normal law, tyrants were often understood to be agents of divine intervention to set right a rotting political culture. So sometimes tyrants were considered necessary or even agents of justice, but they were still doomed to die or be expelled in order to return the city to lawfullness.

So the repressed thing here is that Pisistratis was actually considered a good governor, and he was largely a popular one because he favored common farmers and such. He maintained his rule until he died, and his sons were overthrown by some angry aristocrats. Cleisthenes was basically tasked with doing what Solon did but more effectively, so another tyrant wouldn't arise. He set about changing the political divisions of the state from old tribal divisions to more arbitrary geographic ones resembling census districts (the "demes"), basically jumbling the tribes together. The move was to weaken kinship ties and create more loyal ties to the state as "citizens". A part of this process was deciding who was and was not a "real" Athenian, and the question was won by the Athenian movement for autochthonism. The majority was allowed to vote on whether you were a real Athenian, and if they voted no you were enslaved.

Cont.

>The post-Neolithic demographic history of East-Central Europe, despite this region being on the confluence of various ecological zones and cultural entities is poorly explored. Here, the descendants of societies associated with steppe pastoralists form Early Bronze Age (EBA 2400-1800 BC) were followed by Middle Bronze Age (MBA 1800-1200 BC) populations displaying unique characteristics. Particularly, the predominance of collective burials, the scale of which, was previously seen only in the Neolithic. To study kinship of those MBA societies and to test whether the re-emergence of those old traditions was a result of genetic shift or social changes, we generated and analyzed 91 genomes from individuals associated with EBA and MBA from modern day Poland and Ukraine. Our results indicate that while EBA people in East-Central Europe were most likely direct descendants of the preceding populations, the MBA populations were formed by an additional admixture event involving a population with relatively high proportions of genetic component associated with European hunter-gatherers. Additionally, our data shows that MBA collective burials contained numerous individuals related to each other, and the prevalence of close kinship among adult male descendants over adult female suggests that patrilocality was dominating form of marriage arrangements in these societies.

At the time, Protestantism had spread throughout Germany, even overtaking the all of Bohemia and most of Upper Austria - hereditary lands of the Austrian branch of the Habsburg family - who were the hereditary family controlling the Holy Roman Empire (which can be thought of as a heavily decentralized Germany), although they technically had to be elected to the throne. That same state of being a technically elected monarch stood for the Kingdom of Bohemia. The Bohemians had been promised a degree of religious autonomy by a past Habsburg under the Letter of Majesty. They nevertheless feared the current ruler wouldn't respect such a document due to him being a firm advocate of the Counter Reformation. They eventually chimped out when it appeared the Catholic officials he appointed to the territory offended their delicate Protestant sensibilities and eventually, after a period of revolt that the current Habsburg ruler appeared posed to crush rather than negotiate to the degree of satisfying their delicate Protestant sensibilities, offered the crown to Frederick V of the Palatinate who was the head of a Protestant alliance of states within the Holy Roman Empire. It was believed, by both he and the Bohemians, that his family and diplomatic connections would give him enough support to resist the emperor. Those connections amounted to (almost) dogshit and he had to flee the kingdom after the rebels were crushed. He fled to the Dutch Republic, which was currently embroiled in the Eighty Years' War against the Spanish Habsburgs (which started over a similar situation generations ago) who had pledged to assist their Austrian cousins in order to solidify their control over their string of continental territories which were allowing them to funnel troops to the Dutch front.

These two conflicts which eventually become intertwined.

the Continental style, promoted to London queers by Bill Green, a former physique photographer, who opened Vince Man’s Shop in Soho in the 50s. On a trip to the South of France, he noticed such novelties as black jeans and tight swimming trunks. Rome’s ‘Dolce Vita’ period at the turn of the 60s was the next big influence. Within months of the film’s premiere,Vince marketed “bum freezer” jackets, drain-pipe trousers and winklepicker shoes.

Green’s sales assistant, John Stephen, left to open His Clothes, around the corner in Carnaby Street. Stephen developed his own style, accentuating the male form even further by lowering trousers from the waist to the hips and minimizing underwear (“hipster briefs”) accordingly. This sexy and essentially queer look was appropriated by the mainstream rag trade to dress the Mod era, big from 1963-1966, when The Beatles helped to make London the most swinging city in the world.

By 1967 mods had been replaced by hippies with unisex clothes and shoulder-length hair. For the rest of the decade it was often difficult to determine gender, let alone sexuality. But this situation began to change around 1969, when some working class lads reacted to hippie androgyny by shortening their hair and wearing braces (suspenders).

AS QX said in 1998,“Queers are always first to discover a new drug.” And so it’s always been. Most of the queer bars of the 50s and 60s didn’t serve alcohol. In 1985, F-48 became the Danish National Association of Gays and Lesbians

All the commenters saying OP is crazy because America is presently degenerate, you're wrong but onto something.

OP is correct, the "proper" and widespread American culture for much of its history has been sexually repressed. It valued hard work, levelheadedness, and spiritual faith. It doesn't seem as bad now because we're living after the counterculture movement of the 1960s, which was a direct backlash to 1950s popular American culture (which you might say was the peak expression of the conservative puritanical values that created and symbolize it).

Protestantism laid the groundwork, certainly. But it was also influenced by the American experience, colonizing a harsh and unforgiving land left no time for comforts or excess. Further bolstered by each wave of immigrants, who you'd think would bring diversity and open mindedness, but not so in reality. Immigrant and first generation families actually tend to have strong conservative family values and sensibilities, due to the language/culture barriers creating insular communities, and being generally poor and frugal.

America in its formative years long felt inferior to its European counterparts, despite the fact that culturally you could say it still is a type of European/western nation. This is part of why Americans don't value sexual expression, it conflicts with its strong faith and work-based sensibilities. Popular media and politics still try to retain this type of American culture, if only on its face. We're currently going through a correction of this philosophy, it may seem like it's losing but it's very much still with us.

>>14420330
This is a myth that comes from poor translation from French to English

In French, "troupes coloniales" mainly refered to the white French troops that served in the regiments meant for colonial wars, while localed recruits were called "tirailleurs" (Senegalese Tirailleurs, Algerian Tirailleurs, Tonkinese Tirailleurs....etc).
In English however, "colonial troops" always refers to the brown recruits.
As a result, some white regiments are considered to be "colonial troops" by ill informed anglos and their feats are attributed to brown people.

For exemple,the case of the Colonial Infantry Regiment of Morocco.
It's he most decorated regiment of the French Army and is famous for it's brave recapture of Fort Douaumont in the Battle of Verdun (thus earning the reputationof "shock troops").
>The regiment was composed primarily of metropolitan Frenchmen, in accordance with the infantry of the French Marines.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R%C3%A9giment_d%27infanterie-chars_de_marine#World_War_I

So basically, "colonial troops" didn't mean non-whites in the French army.
Non-whites were "tirailleurs".
Pic related, French colonial troops.

posts.com:
>>14422887
A combination of factors:
1. The main powers of Greece (Aetolians, Achaean League) had been looking to get their independence from the Big Kids on the block (Antigonid Macedon, Seleucid Syria), so they sought to bring in Rome as a third party/even Bigger Kid who ended up mopping the floor with both powers. Rome paid pretty good lip service to the Greeks for much of the second century, until they went scorched earth around 150s-140s after being dragged into so many disputes. The destruction of Corinth in 146, the dissolution of the Macedonian monarchy, and enslavement of 150,000 Epirotes really fucked their shit up and discouraged further rebellion for the next 50 years.
2. By the late 2nd/early 1st century BC, Rome was still pretty new to the "empire administration" thing, and their system of extracting taxes via intermediary contracts led to some extremely predatory Romans squeezing every last drop out of the wealthier provinces of Asia Minor. This led to some really strong resentment amongst the peoples of the area.
3. Mithridates was an extremely competent and ambitious ruler, and realized early on that it was probably a matter of time before he was going to have to deal with Rome somehow. Coincidentally, the Republic was suffering serious internal problems during his reign (post-Gracchi political violence, the Civil Wars of Marius/Sulla, the Social War, the Second Servile War), which allowed him to build up enough power without Roman interference. The fractious nature of Late Republican Rome enabled someone like Mithridates to take advantage of their distractions and infighting, while the Republic between 200 BC and 150 BC was unified enough to curbstomp anyone that so much as farted in the wrong direction. The fact that he still failed in spite of Rome's issues is a testament to just how strong the Republic still was.

"Even when the Mithridates known as “Founder” proclaimed himself king in the early years of the 3rd century BCE, and the family adopted some of the ways of Hellenism and Hellenistic courts, in particular the use of Greek as the official language, they continued proudly to proclaim their royal Achaemenid lineage: their search for respectability and legitimization through Persian descent attests a deep and powerful Persian ethos in the people of Pontus. The most famous member of the family, Mithridates VI Eupator (ca. 120-63 BCE), although undoubtedly presenting himself to the Greek world as a civilized philhellene and new Alexander, also paraded his Iranian background: he maintained a harem and eunuchs in true Oriental fashion; he gave all his sons Persian names; he sacrificed spectacularly in the manner of the Persian kings at Pasargadae (Appian, Mith. 66, 70); and he appointed “satraps” (a Persian title) as his provincial governors. And although there is only one inscription attesting it, he seems to have adopted the title “king of kings.” The very small number of Hellenistic Greek inscriptions that have been found anywhere in Pontus suggest that Greek culture did not substantially penetrate beyond the coastal cities and the court."

Their presumption is that since Dahomey's economy was dominated by revenues from slave trade, that the state's political and economic objectives were dictated by slave trade.

There's little evidence for this however

Studies on Dahomey's economy show that external slave trade was only a marginal component of the domestic economy;

the lowest and highest estimates place the share of external slave trade in Dahomey's economy at at between 2.5% and 15%

>What made your childhood great
not much. it sucked in many ways. but I had the privilege of - partly - growing up in a historic setting, in a small village in the northeastern swamp area, in the house of my paternal grandparents, which was built of adobe, with a reed thatch roof, no electricity, no running water, no nothing, moving in synch with the ancient peasant's life cycles. I am coming to you from at least 3-500 years ago.
>and if you could go back to being a kid, what would you want to re-experience
the summer morning fog between the trees behind the house. full moon over the snow-covered village. the taste of homemade bread. all the smells and sounds of village life.
sorry, made me nostalgic. all this happened 50 years ago, and nothing remains of that lifestyle anymore. in a few cases I visited open-air exhibits of peasant life with my family and I often get into arguments with the personnel, because frankly, they are clueless about how even basic stuff should be presented - putting the pulling knob on the wrong side of the door, chimney breaking through the roof in the wrong place, that sort of retardation.

>Miss being a kid?
Sometimes. I had a great childhood. But I also enjoy being an adult and don't want to give up on all the experiences I've had, knowledge and skills I've gained. If anything I miss being in my late teens/early 20s. Wish I could have my body from back then while keeping my current mind. Youth is wasted on the young.
>What made your childhood great
My parents were cool. They fought fairly often but always made up. My mom went above and beyond with holidays. Christmas was always magical, we still have the best tree I've ever seen. We'd put out carrots for the reindeer and cookies for Santa. Stockings were filled with small gifts and the rest appeared under the tree before we woke up. Since she lived in Germany as a kid, we also celebrated St. Nicolas Day on the 6th (Nikolaustag). We'd put our shoes out by the fireplace the night before, and wake up to them filled with candy.

I also had a decent number of friends, brothers who I was close with, and was surrounded by pets. I loved playing with my dog, an abnormally large Australian Shepard. I played a ton of video games and even started making my own once I got RPG Maker. Since I had brothers, I always had people to play multiplayer with. Tons of Goldeneye, Mario Kart, and Halo. Our childhood neighborhood was also full of kids our age, and our parents let us wander around freely back in those days. Lived right by a park with a giant concrete slide.
>if you could go back to being a kid, what would you want to re-experience or experience for the first time that you never did?
I'd want to be with my pets and grandparents again. That's the main thing.

>In 1738, Pope Clement XII prohibited Catholics from becoming Freemasons, on the grounds that the order required secret oaths, involved paganistic rituals, and encouraged religious indifferentism. But like papal decrees before and after, many Catholics blithely decided to ignore the prohibition and joined the masons, anyway. They thought that those who took such bans seriously were being stuffy and getting in the way of progress. Lawyers, doctors, merchants, artists, writers, ladies, aristocrats, kings and emperors, who were otherwise practicing Catholics, were initiated into various lodges, lodges which often rivaled each other with different goals and endeavors

>In the family of Marie-Antoinette there were some members who were masons, including her father Emperor Francis I. Her mother, Empress Maria Theresa, was vehemently against masonry. The Empress sent the police to raid one of the lodges while her husband the Emperor was at a meeting, and he had to escape by a back staircase

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>While there is no evidence that Marie-Antoinette was herself ever initiated into a lodge, she went through a time when she was favorable to freemasonry. Her close friend, the virtuous Madame de Lamballe, presided over the Lodge of the Social Contract, one of the ladies' lodges or loges d'adoption. In 1781, Madame de Lamballe became Grand Mistress of all of the Lodges of Adoption in France. That same year, Marie-Antoinette wrote to a friend, praising the good works of the masonic sisterhood, and how they provided dowries for poor girls and were very pious. She also praised them in a letter to her sister Marie-Christine, saying: "It is only a society of benevolence and pleasure." (see Nesta Webster's Louis XVI and Marie-Antoinette Before the Revolution, p. 237-238) She and Louis XVI both saw the masons as a means of charitable works to benefit society, and they both may have at one point visited certain lodges, so that to this day, some masonic groups claim them as their own

>There is also evidence that Marie-Antoinette's best friend Madame de Polignac was a member of a ladies' lodge, although not to the extent that Madame de Lamballe was involved; it was considered the fashionable thing to do. Nesta Webster, who blames the masons for practically everything, said that the Lodges of Adoption were harmless enough ladies' clubs. They were probably one step away from the Mopses, but still, in my opinion, Catholics should not have joined, since masonry was forbidden by the Church

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>As for Louis XVI, there has long been a debate as to if he was ever formally initiated into a lodge as his brothers probably were. When he ascended the throne, Louis XVI was quite liberal and progressive; like all young progressives at the time he saw the masons not only as harmless, but as a group who would benefit society by active good works. Some of this explains his initial acquiescence to certain measures in the beginning of the Revolution which were damaging to the Church, especially the Civil Constitution of the Clergy. He admits as much in the Vow to the Sacred Heart which he made under house arrest in the Tuileries in 1791

>It is true that many monarchists were masons and many revolutionaries were not masons. However, in the years preceding the Revolution of 1789, masonic lodges formed a network that fomented discord, spread propaganda against the King and especially against the Queen. The lodges were used by a core of aristocrats and politicians who wanted to secularize society, and destroy the Church, or at least enervate it, by destroying or by seizing the crown

>Marie-Antoinette came to see this quite clearly. In August of 179o she wrote to her brother Emperor Leopold of Austria: "Be well on your guard where you are with regard to all associations of Freemasons. You must already have been warned that it is by this means that all monsters here count on attaining the same end in every country. Oh, God, preserve my Fatherland and you from such misfortunes." ( Lettres de Marie-Antoinette, edited by Maxime de la Rocheterie, 2 vol., 1895) For Marie-Antoinette and Louis XVI, the warnings had not been heeded, until it was too late
